title: Riots Solution to Immobile Mages (make them more mobile)

It's probably not that they absolutely cannot buy them, but I imagine that they have other needs as well that also need to be met. LeBlanc, for example, probably needs to solve Mana issues, and this item doesn't help her do that at all. Fizz delays Lich Bane or Zhonya's to get this, or he gets it instead of something with more raw damage like a Void Staff.

Maybe it's just overkill on champions that already have mobility, and so they won't frequently buy it. Or maybe it's broken and they always will! These are the kinds of things worth testing. There's definitely some sort of tension in AP itemization where buying something feels like giving up something else (at least temporarily), so I imagine that holds true here as well, but we'll see.

I think one critical question to answer is whether more mobility gives diminishing or increasing returns.

# If mobility gives diminishing returns, then less-mobile Champions gain more from these items
If giving a Champion +1 blink has diminishing returns, then I think creating broader access to mobility (through items, spells, etc.) is an effective way to "nerf" hyper-mobile Champions without actually taking away mobility those Champions are built around. In a "diminishing returns" model, your first flash gives tons of extra power, your next flash gives you somewhat less additional power, and so on. This might the case because, for instance, a match contains a sequence of "flash opportunities" that can be "purchased" by using a flash, and people who play smart will naturally tend to reserve their flash for the highest-value opportunities; additional flashes, then, simply let you buy second-best options, and third-best options, and so on. For example, let's say there are three opportunities: (1) Flash-baron-steal-ace (2) strong teamfight initiation (3) escaping a gank. A hyper-mobile Champion with two blinks might use the rocket belt to also pick up the third option, a moderate gain. But an immobile Champion with only one blink to start with would pick up the second option, a significant gain.

# If mobility gives increasing returns, then more-mobile Champions gain more from these items
If giving a Champion +1 blink has increasing returns, then it's quite the opposite, as already-mobile Champions will gain more from these items than their less-mobile peers. An increasing returns situation would be one where, e.g., you can do awesome things with two flashes used in sequence that you could never do with just one, and thus a Champion going from one flash to two flashes gains more power than another Champion who goes from zero flashes to one flash.

# In a diminishing-returns scenario, this item might be a good way to help less-mobile Champions
My intuition is that, on most Champions and in most circumstances, mobility has diminishing returns, so I'm tentatively for something like the rocket belt. I say "tentatively" because, as you yourself are obviously fully aware, it could have all kinds of unforeseen, complex outcomes. (Cue Jeff Goldblum.)

# Concluding note: the PBE is (in part) for wild and crazy experimentation, so why not try it?
But I'm unambiguously in favor of *trying* it, at least on PBE. Isn't this part of what PBE is for? Getting large-volume, rapid feedback on sometimes quite revolutionary proposed changes. Sometimes I almost feel like Riot should distinguish between PBE updates, e.g., as "first-run" versus "pre-release". With the former being "hey let's see what happens" initial changes, and the latter being "okay, we're pretty sure we want this on live, so we're just running it through PBE for bug checks and stuff" revisions. That way, people might not freak out so much when they see "first-run" changes that give Tryndamere an AoE knockup ultimate and retcon Amumu's lore to a story about a trick-or-treater cursed to wear his bad mummy costume forever.
